item.title: [tut]Roll diceee
item.dc:creator: @Lysol Lysol
item.description:
@Lysol wrote:

Math.random() returns a double value. A double value is an interger with a decimal, basically. The “(int)” is there to “cast” the double that Math.random() returns, as an int. When a double is cast as an int, the int value will be everything from the begining to the decimal (1.23 will turn into 1, 3.99 will turn int 3). Math.random() returns a double anywere from 0.0 - 0.99. This is why he multiplys by 6, and then adds 1. If Math.random() returns 0.99, it will be multiplied by 6, resulting in 5.94. 5.94 will then be cast to an integer, 5. Now, 0.99 is the max number Math.random() will return, when there are 6 sides to a die. That is add 1 to it, same principal if Math.random() returns 0.00.

Theres a little more detail for ya.

Read full topic

item.title: [tut]Roll diceee
item.dc:creator: @RegeX RegeX
item.description:
@RegeX wrote:

Also, you can avoid using Math.random(), and use a seeded java.util.Random object:

java.util.Random rand = new java.util.Random(optional seed);
int rand = rand.nextInt(6);

Read full topic

item.title: [tut]Roll diceee
item.dc:creator: @pistolbob pistolbob
item.description:
@pistolbob wrote:

okay heres a tut on making a program that simulates rolling the dice.
ok first you always need the class name which for this lets call it 

class RollDice
  • the standardness stuff 

 public static void main (String[] args)
{

and now we have to name our integers.

int die1;
 int die2;
 int roll;

this signafies that you have the word die1 and die2 saving numbers to them and roll is also doing the same.
and now to tell it to do something with those integers,

die1 = (int) (Math.random()*6) + 1;
die2 = (int) (math.random()*6) + 1;
roll = die1 + die2;

this is telling it to multiply a random number by 6 and add 1 to it and save it to die1 and do the same for die2
roll is saving the totall of die1 + die2
and now for it to display this information,

System.out.println("The first die comes up " + die1);
System.out.println("The second die comes up" + die2);
System.out.println("Your total roll is" + roll);

this is telling it to print in the die1 roll and the die2 roll, and then show the sum of the two.
this is a pretty basic program but you can add it to a game or something or do what you wish... have Fun...
Pistolbob

Read full topic
